title: Who won Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions?
text:
Twist and Pulse are your BGT The Champions champions (Picture: ITV)

We have our Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions winner.

Making up for Paul Potts’ shock exit and no Susan Boyle, Britain claimed both gold and silver in last night’s final.

Keep reading to find out who took home the gold and glory…

Who won BGT: Champions?

Dance duo Twist and Pulse won BGT: the Champions last night.

They pipped Stavros Flatley to the post, with the father-son comedy/dance act (who are not breaking up, they’ll have you know) coming in second.

After Ant and Dec crowned them the champs, Twist and Pulse’s Ashley Glazebrook said: ‘Things like this don’t happen to me and my best friend Glen… this means the world to us.’

If they’re considered something of a surprise winner, even the judges agreed.

After their performance, Simon Cowell called them ‘the underdogs of the competition’ – and they proved every underdog has its day.

Where did everyone else come on the BGT: Champions final?

The way the show was structured, only the top three acts were announced.

From there, Ant and Dec revealed which two acts had the most public votes and eventually who the winners were.

When it came time to announce the three acts with the most votes, even the judges couldn’t guess correctly.

Waiting to hear who was through, Simon whispered to Amanda Holden, David Walliams and Alesha Dixon, ‘I think it’s the dogs’ referring to German Das Supertalent’s Alexa Lauenburger.

Who were the top three on Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions?

First announced through was Ukraine’s Got Talent winner Kseniya Simonova, who received the show’s first golden buzzer.

Following her was Twist and Pulse and finally Stavros Flatley.

Ant and Dec then revealed that Kseniya would be finishing third, leaving the two British acts in the final two.

As the final two waited to hear who won, it was clear there wasn’t a frontrunner.

After Stavros Flatley performed last night, Amanda told them, ‘You just make us feel good’ which Simon repeated and added: ‘Right now in this country we just want to feel good.’

Twist and Pulse were called an ‘11’ out of 10 from David Walliams and Simon commended them for having all ‘6000 people [at Wembley Arena] on their feet’.
